How to remember the humanity years:
1. Add number 1 in front of the current year in gregorian calendar (ex: 2021 -> 12021)
2. Add coma before two Numbers in front of it (ex: 12021 -> 12,021)
3. Voila, there you have it guys that's how do you read + remember the humanity years

Why not give us a downloadable calendar? It saves trees and if we want to print it out, we can do so. Plus it allows you to offer it at a more affordable rate. There's a downloadable lunar calendar I was looking at last week that gives you the times of the Rise & Set of the sun and moon, it notes when you can see other planets in the sky, it notes all the phases & types of the moon, it notes all the eclipses and meteor showers, it notes all the equinoxes and retrogrades, etc. That's functional and fun. I would pay for that, plus you can download it as a weekly planner & punch it into a 3-ring binder -- or take it to Office Max where they can bind it for you. Annnd laminate it to be shiny!

Like at least with this kind, I have options to choose how I want my calendar. Yours doesn't do any of that. I'll support you when your calendar's best feature (the cover) isn't hidden when hung up, bc it's facing the wall where I can't even see it. If the interior is where I'm going to be seeing/using it the most -- and it's a bunch of boring blank boxes -- then it's not worth it. Hopefully you take this advice into consideration for future calendars. Also, hire me, I've got cool ideas.

I use the Hebrew Calendar, but I fully support the integration of a secular one like this one. So many people will claim they don't believe in Jesus or G-D or that somehow they are part of a secular nation, but then they'll forced everyone to date time by counting the years since the alleged existence of a pagan antisemitic idol who preached a genocide known as the Armageddon. I mean that Gregorian Calendar was literally created by a Pope for the purpose of practicing Christianity. It has no secondary purpose. We cannot plant a crop by it, hence Farmer's Almanacs being a thing. We cannot sail by it, hence tidal charts being a thing. It isn't even all that accurate, hence leap years and resets. Like I understand the Hebrew calendar is a religious calendar, but at least I can plan a harvest around it so it has some real world reason to exist outside of the religion.

This year has sucked, everyone knows that. There’s so much that’s happened that I wish hadn’t, but it’s important not to dwell on the past. Kurzgesagt, I’m not sure if you’ll see this comment, but thank you for everything you’ve done and everything you’ve posted in the past however long. In this world where so much unnecessary suffering has come from a place lacking empathy and fact, you’ve been a beacon of hope. You’ve inspired me over the years to pursue science, to make my mark on a world that can, and hopefully will, be better. Im in awe of your ability as a channel to take such important and complicated subject material and make it something accessible and enjoyable for a wider audience.

I’m hoping with this bundle to be kinder to myself so that maybe I can be a better person for those who I have an impact on. 2020 is a year most of us would rather not look back on, but maybe it’s more important to look back and accept rather than try to ignore and forget.

Sorry for kind of a long comment, and thank you again for everything. I look forward to whatever you post in the future, and for my calendar and gratitude journal (birds and all). Keep doing what you’re doing, and here’s to hopefully a happy ending to 12020.
